meanings.definition: A person who deceives others by pretending to have more skill or knowledge than they actually possess.
meanings.sent1: The bluffer claimed to be an expert in chess, but was quickly exposed as a beginner.
meanings.sent2: The poker player was known as a bluffer, always making others believe he had a winning hand.
meanings.sent3: The bluffer tried to convince everyone he could speak five languages fluently, but his accent gave him away.
meanings.sent4: She was a bluffer in the art world, pretending to know famous painters when she couldn't even name one.
meanings.sent5: The young boy was a bluffer, trying to impress his friends with made-up stories of his adventures.

meanings.definition: To deceive or mislead someone by pretending to have more skill or knowledge than one actually possesses.
meanings.sent1: He would often bluffer his way through job interviews, claiming expertise in areas he knew nothing about.
meanings.sent2: She decided to bluffer her way out of trouble by pretending she had permission to be there.
meanings.sent3: The comedian liked to bluffer the audience by making up ridiculous facts during his stand-up routine.
meanings.sent4: The politician tried to bluffer the voters with promises he knew he couldn't keep.
meanings.sent5: The student tried to bluffer his teacher by pretending he had studied for the test, but his blank paper gave him away.
